pros: The students are fantastic, it's interesting to see all the projects they are involved in from working at Glastonbury Festival, fashion shows and all their artwork displayed around campus
cons: Endless rounds of redundancy. Just as you think you've survived another round opens. Also no budget for many of the things you need to be able to work smoothly.

review_title: Great place to study, would not recommend as employer
pros: Generous amount of holidays per year plus Christmas closure
cons:
I have worked at Solent university for 5 years and I have people close to me who continue working there. Unfortunately what I observed was that the company culture changes every few years when new leadership takes over. This means things can change drastically and those who are not able to adapt are targeted with redundancy.
The departments and management spend so much time competing (while being constantly reminded of how expendable they all are) that there is not much actual work getting done and the brunt of the work falls to low earning team leaders, low salary employees and fixed-term contract temps. The departments often don't react to calls for action from each other, I am not sure if this is to sabotage management they do not approve or because they are eager to seem busy and overworked. For someone who's looking to get things done, Solent on the inside does not promote collaboration and efficiency.
While the holiday allowance is generous, the pay in a lot of cases does not match industry averages. In my experience, because I was not the most confident or sociable of people, I have felt like I had two choices: either get in line or get out, the latter option being difficult considering the influence the organisation holds over employers within the city.

 Lastly, while the values sound great they are no more than a catchy bait for talented and naive job seekers who Solent are keen to exploit and toss away at the end of their probation, fixed term contract etc.

pros: Flexible working Small class size Small teams
cons: Workload Module changes due to staff turnaround

review_title: Yet another reorganisation of the deck chairs
pros: Some teams can be tight knit. You'll get promoted if your face fits.
cons: Yet another reorganisation due to the university shrinking from a medium size university to a small one. Experienced staff stripped out, which means more work for those who have already absorbed an increased workload resultant from the last round of redundancies.

review_title: Used to be good....now it's crap
pros: Flexibility, annual leave days, closing for holidays
cons: Too many changes happening without having the time for the changes to take affect. Higher management (VCG) doesn't understand what the people who work and implement changes do and how it impacts students. No clear goals or plans.

pros: Flexible working environment between on-sight and from home office. Great facilities.

job_title: Course Leader and Lecturer in Southampton, England
pros: fabulous facilities. some truly excellent lecturers and fellow colleagues. The students are diverse and the range of courses offered brings in a real diversity in teaching staff.
cons: You're definitely going to need to be in a union. The management for the past few years has been appalling with high staff turnover. Lots of changes with schools/faculties being reshaped and departments being merged means a lot of confusion and uncertainty still present.

review_title: Miserable, pressurised environment. Regular redundancies; increased workloads.  Brutal HR.
pros: Excellent facilities in some buildings. Most colleagues. Solent Voice/UCU support.
cons:
Too many academics being made redundant leading to increased seminar group sizes and less individual for support students. 
Less time to research/update teaching content, so inevitably leading to lower standards. Unrewarding environment. 
Brutal HR management, unable to deal with (and sometimes even to acknowledge) bullying which has led to some catastrophic consequences.
Promotions are often political rather than on merit.
Academic workload planning system is unrealistic and designed not to acknowledge much of the work that needs to be carried out as part of the role if you care about your students’ university experience and outcome.

review_title: Was good in the past but increasingly admin and bureaucracy heavy
job_title: Lecturer In Illustration in Southampton, England
pros: Great academic staff who are a joy to work with,  good facilities for the students. Keen to develop international  links
cons:
Too much admin as everything is centralised on a portal. Recent Job losses have been hard to swallow after management spent 30 million on 
Space age architecture to attract new students

pros: pay, bank holidays off, Christmas shut down off, Easter shutdown off. pension scheme,  alot of
cons: they treat their staff like second class citizens, don`t make staff aware of reasons for making terrible un needed changes to working practices, brush an awful lot of problems under the carpet and pretend they are not happening,and fob staff off.  lie to agencies to achieve green impact awards and other things. not really an equal opportunities employer, just pretend they are on paper., don`t really care about the students, just the income from them . i could go on for ever!

review_title: Deeply depressing employer who will grind you into the ground...
pros: Most of the students are great, and many of the staff are fantastic - both on the teaching and support side.
cons:
Bullying is endemic in the organisation (staff survey showed nearly 1 in 5 either bullied or at risk of bullying), bullying managers are protected and have, at times, been encouraged by HR.  Grievance process doesn't work for staff.
Recent redundancies are about creating a climate of fear so staff accept procedures which don't comply with contract conditions.  Speaking out is likely to put you next in line for redundancy.

pros: nothing to add on this section , thanks
cons:
This university has a very poor management staff,  Especially  the line managers in some departments, they are not very polite  and have a bad attitude towards their staff. Also have no idea about what is going on in their job, basically this university appoint people at the management level who are not qualified for their positions.  
Lack of management communication skills and wrong positions given to line managers  is a massive problem,  Solent university will end up losing their Staff, Students and reputation. ((Very disappointing ))

pros: Working at the University has been an amazing stepping stone.
